avalancheActivity.comment:
Saturday: Afternoon: In some localities 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m, especially along the border with France.
The wind will be moderate. Fresh wind slabs will form especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, especially on very steep slopes.
In high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and the danger is greater.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
avalancheActivity.highlights: In some localities increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.

snowpackStructure.comment:
5 to 15 cm of snow, and up to 20 cm in some localities, fell during the night above approximately 2200 m. In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2200 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. On steep sunny slopes below approximately 2500 m a little snow is lying.
The snowpack is not distinctly layered.
Shady slopes: The snowpack consists of faceted crystals and has faceted crystals on the surface.
Below approximately 2300 m: As a consequence of rain a crust formed on the surface.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger will persist. The wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.

avalancheActivity.comment:
In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 2 (moderate) and along the border with Switzerland 2 to 10 cm of snow will fall until the early morning above approximately 1800 m.
The wind will be moderate in some localities.
Wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitudes and in the high Alpine regions. They are mostly small and can only be released in isolated cases. These avalanche prone locations are to be found on extremely steep slopes, in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind slabs in the high Alpine regions. This applies in particular above approximately 2500 m.

regions.name: B - VALLI DI GRESSONEY, AYAS, CHAMPORCHER

snowpackStructure.comment:
2 to 10 cm of snow, but less in some localities, fell during the night above approximately 2200 m. In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2200 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. On sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m hardly any snow is lying. Also on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m hardly any snow is lying.
The snowpack is largely stable. It is not distinctly layered.
Shady slopes: The snowpack consists of faceted crystals and has faceted crystals on the surface.
Below approximately 2200 m: As a consequence of rain a crust formed on the surface on Friday.
